newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan dlr ends down; political jitters continue.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan dlr ends down; political jitters continue.

text.p: The Taiwan dollar closed at an 11-month low against its U.S. counterpart on Tuesday, as political jitters ahead of a planned cabinet reshuffle spurred a foreign funds outflow begun on Monday, dealers said.
The local unit closed at T$27.778 against Monday's T$27.759 finish. It was the rate's lowest close since it finished at T$27.790 on June 8, 1996.
Turnover through dealers was a hectic US$375.5 million.
The dollar had fallen sharply on Monday against the greenback, driven down by the withdrawal of millions of dollars in foreign equity from the plunging stock market.
Share prices again fell on Tuesday, but by only 0.18 percent -- far less than Monday's huge 3.72 percent selloff.

Anti-government sentiment in Taiwan erupted in April following the kidnap and murder of a famous actress's teenage daughter, triggering widespread calls for a cabinet reshuffle and the resignation of Premier Lien Chan.
Lien, who said on Monday he would resign in July, was expected to propose a mild cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday.
Parliament narrowly defeated an opposition-sponsored motion that would have urged President Lee Teng-hui to sack Lien and order a sweeping cabinet reshuffle.
"The political concerns right now are causing the Taiwan dollar to depreciate," said one dealer.
"But it is a depreciation which the government, and the central bank in particular, does not mind seeing," he added.
Many dealers and analysts believe the government welcomes a modest depreciation of the Taiwan dollar, which would spur exports -- the island's economic lifeblood.
A T$27.76-80 range was seen for Wednesday.
